newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan Union Bank to raise capital by 9 mln dinars.
newsitem.headline: Jordan Union Bank to raise capital by 9 mln dinars.

text.p: Jordan's Union Bank for Savings and Investment announced on Tuesday it was raising its capital by nine million dinars ($12.7 million) to meet a Central Bank capital requirement of 20 million dinars.

It said the capital increase would come from a private placement of nine million shares offered at a 1.5 dinars each, raising a total of 13.5 million dinars. Nine million would go to the capital raise and another 4.5 into shareholders rights.
Subscription for the offering opens on November 9 and closes on December 9, the bank said.
"This capital hike is to strengthen the bank in line with the Central Bank's policy," Issam Salfiti, general manager of Union Bank for Savings and Investment told Reuters.
It has already received commitments from existing shareholders to cover at least five million shares, bank officials said.
Union Bank has been raising its capital since last year in three stages to reach a 20 million dinar minimum capital ceiling by mid-1997 under a Central bank deadline.

Its last capital raise was at end of last year when it increased it to 11 million dinars from 9 million dinars by private placement. That followed a 1.8 million dinar increase from the bank's original 7.2 million dinar capital.
The key shareholder of the bank, which approved the capital raise in an extraordinary AGM last September, is Jordan's Salfiti family which owns at least 40 percent of its capital.
Another 23 percent key is owned by U.K.-based Sirt Securities International. Jordan's Housing Bank has a minority 6 percent holding.

The bank saw a significant rise in its assets to 190.5 million dinars at end of 1995, a 19 percent increase over the previous year. Its loans portfolio stood at 57.5 million dinars at end of 1995. Deposits rose 21 percent to 157.6 million dinars at end of 1995.
The bank, one of Jordan's six investment banks, opened its first non Jordanian branch in the West Bank town of Ramallah earlier this year.
